elements.content: The imidazole donor ligand bis(4-imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-diazene (azim) reacts readily with M(ClO4)2·6H2O [M(II) = Zn(II) and Cu(II)] salts at room temperature to afford {[Zn(azim)2]·(ClO4)2·3DMF} n (1) and {[Cu(azim)2(DMF)2]·(ClO4)2·2DMF} n (2) (DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide). With MCl2·6H2O [M(II) = Zn(II) and Cu(II)] salts under solvothermal conditions, compounds {[Zn(azim)(HCOO)2]} n (3) and {[Cu(azim)(Cl)]} n (4) are obtained in moderate yields. Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize as 2D four-connected 44 sql networks with rectangular and rhombus grids, respectively. The frameworks are stabilized by an intricate array of hydrogen bonding interactions with guest molecules that also results in overall 3D frameworks. On the other hand, complexes 3 and 4 form 1D zigzag infinite chain structures. All compounds have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. The TGA and PXRD measurements reveal that the integrity of the frameworks 1 and 2 is maintained upon guest removal. N2 and CO2 adsorption measurements were carried out for evacuated frameworks 1 and 2, and the adsorption studies show CO2 selectivity over N2 at low pressure in the case of 2. Interestingly, heat and guest induced bicycle pedal motion of the azo moiety can be observed in 1 and 4 without loss of crystallinity. Upon excitation at 304 nm, compounds 1–4 and 4′ exhibit solid-state luminescence at room temperature.

With MCl2⋅6H2O [M(II) = Zn(II) and Cu(II)] salts under solvothermal conditions, compounds {[Zn(azim)(HCOO)2]} n  (3) and {[Cu(azim)(Cl)]} n  (4) are obtained in moderate yields. elements.content: Four novel coordination polymers based on zinc and copper ions have been synthesized. The pore surfaces of all the frameworks are decorated with azo functional groups having basic nitrogen sites. Interestingly, frameworks 1 and 4 exhibit bicycle pedal motion when subjected to external stimuli. Gas adsorption measurements and luminescence properties have also been explored.
elements.clean_text: Four novel coordination polymers based on zinc and copper ions have been synthesized. The pore surfaces of all the frameworks are decorated with azo functional groups having basic nitrogen sites. Interestingly, frameworks 1 and 4 exhibit bicycle pedal motion when subjected to external stimuli. Gas adsorption measurements and luminescence properties have also been explored.

elements.content: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a new class of hybrid inorganic–organic materials with intriguing topologies. These compounds have been used as potential candidates in ion exchange, catalysis, gas storage, separation, luminescence, and other studies. More recently, frameworks whose structure and properties can be tuned by external factors, such as guest molecules, or physical stimuli, such as heat or light, are being explored. When the organic linker contains moieties that can undergo rotation, dynamic motion may occur in the framework in the solid state. Such molecular motion serves to explain various dynamic aspects of molecules besides being potentially useful in fabricating molecular devices. We had earlier observed bicycle pedal motion with the ligand (Scheme ) in the coordination polymer built with Cd(II) ion. We further show here that CPs built with other metal ions also shows such pedal motion in response to external stimuli without losing crystallinity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a new class of hybrid inorganic-organic materials with intriguing topologies. These compounds have been used as potential candidates in ion exchange, catalysis, gas storage, separation, luminescence, and other studies. More recently, frameworks whose structure and properties can be tuned by external factors, such as guest molecules, or physical stimuli, such as heat or light, are being explored. When the organic linker contains moieties that can undergo rotation, dynamic motion may occur in the framework in the solid state. Such molecular motion serves to explain various dynamic aspects of molecules besides being potentially useful in fabricating molecular devices. We had earlier observed bicycle pedal motion with the ligand (Scheme ) in the coordination polymer built with Cd(II) ion. We further show here that CPs built with other metal ions also shows such pedal motion in response to external stimuli without losing crystallinity.

elements.content: Synthesis of PCPs with guest-accessible functional sites on the pore surface is a very challenging task because the functional groups tend to coordinate metal ions as well making such compounds inaccessible for guest molecules. However, successful design of functional sites in the linker that can serve as Lewis acid/base sites play an important role in selective gas adsorption. In recent years, selective CO2 adsorption has been one of the major areas of research due to the uncontrollable rise of the atmospheric CO2 concentration levels, which is one of the primary environmental concerns.

In recent years, selective CO2 adsorption has been one of the major areas of research due to the uncontrollable rise of the atmospheric CO2 concentration levels, which is one of the primary environmental concerns.

elements.content: Herein, we report four new coordination polymers with the ligand and zinc/copper ions, {[Zn(azim)2]·(ClO4)2·3DMF} n (1), {[Cu(azim)2(DMF)2]·(ClO4)2·2DMF} n (2), {[Zn(azim)(HCOO)2]} n (3), and {[Cu(azim)(Cl)]} n (4), and evaluate them for possible bicycle pedal motion and selective gas adsorption studies. Solid-state luminescence of 1–4 and 4′ at room temperature is also described.

elements.content: Reagent grade 4-fluoronitrobenzene, imidazole, Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O, Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O, ZnCl2·6H2O, and CuCl2·6H2O salts were procured from Aldrich and used as received. N,N′-dimethylformamide, methanol, K2CO3, and zinc dust were acquired from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. All solvents were purified prior to use.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Reagent grade 4-fluoronitrobenzene, imidazole, Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, ZnCl2⋅6H2O, and CuCl2⋅6H2O salts were procured from Aldrich and used as received. N,N'-dimethylformamide, methanol, K2CO3, and zinc dust were acquired from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. All solvents were purified prior to use.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) on a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were recorded on Mettler Toledo Star System (heating rate of 5 °C/min). Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Jobin Yvon Horiba Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction (Cu Kα radiation, scan rate 3°/min, 293 K) was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance Series 2 powder X-ray diffractometer. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric Quantachrome Autosorb-1C adsorption equipment. Prior to adsorption measurements, the complexes 1 and 2 were immersed in dichloromethane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature followed by heating at 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) on a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were recorded on Mettler Toledo Star System (heating rate of 5 °C/min). Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Jobin Yvon Horiba Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter at room temperature. Powder X-ray diffraction (Cu Kα radiation, scan rate 3°/min, 293 K) was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance Series 2 powder X-ray diffractometer. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric Quantachrome Autosorb-1C adsorption equipment. Prior to adsorption measurements, the complexes 1 and 2 were immersed in dichloromethane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature followed by heating at 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data on compounds 1–4 and 4′ were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. The data were processed as described earlier. In each case, the structure was solved by the direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-97 program package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. For compound 1, squeeze refinement has been performed using PLATON that shows 2.25 N,N′-dimethylformamide molecules per formula weight. The contributions of all the solvent atoms have been incorporated in both the empirical formula and formula weight. In case of 4′, the H atoms of the lattice water molecule were located in difference Fourier maps and refined keeping the O–H bond distances constrained to ∼0.85 Å with the DFIX command. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table while selective bond distances and angles are given in Table S1, .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Studies

Single-crystal X-ray data on compounds 1-4 and 4' were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. The data were processed as described earlier. In each case, the structure was solved by the direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-97 program package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. For compound 1, squeeze refinement has been performed using PLATON that shows 2.25 N,N'-dimethylformamide molecules per formula weight. The contributions of all the solvent atoms have been incorporated in both the empirical formula and formula weight. In case of 4', the H atoms of the lattice water molecule were located in difference Fourier maps and refined keeping the O-H bond distances constrained to ~0.85 Å with the DFIX command. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table  while selective bond distances and angles are given in Table S1, .

The ligand bis(4-imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-diazene was synthesized in two steps as described earlier.

Synthesis of {[Zn(azim)<sub>2</sub>]·(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·3DMF}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A hot DMF solution (3 mL) of the ligand (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added to 2 mL of mixed MeOH/H2O (1:1, v/v) solution containing Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O (∼60 mg, 0.16 mmol). On slow evaporation of the filtrate at RT, red crystals were obtained in ∼43% yield. Anal. Calcd for C45H49Cl2N15O11Zn: C, 48.59; H, 4.44; N, 18.88%. Found: C, 48.68; H, 4.51; N, 18.96%. IR (cm–1): 3119(m), 2927(w), 2854(w), 1669(s), 1602(m), 1526(s), 1435(w), 1407(m), 1335(m), 1308(s), 1092(s), 1008(s), 849(s), 773(m), 656(s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligand (azim)

The ligand bis(4-imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-diazene was synthesized in two steps as described earlier. 

Synthesis of {[Zn(azim)2]⋅(ClO4)2⋅3DMF} n  (1)

A hot DMF solution (3 mL) of the ligand (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added to 2 mL of mixed MeOH/H2O (1:1, v/v) solution containing Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (~60 mg, 0.16 mmol). On slow evaporation of the filtrate at RT, red crystals were obtained in ~43% yield. Anal. Calcd for C45H49Cl2N15O11Zn: C, 48.59; H, 4.44; N, 18.88%. Found: C, 48.68; H, 4.51; N, 18.96%. IR (cm-1): 3119(m), 2927(w), 2854(w), 1669(s), 1602(m), 1526(s), 1435(w), 1407(m), 1335(m), 1308(s), 1092(s), 1008(s), 849(s), 773(m), 656(s).

elements.content: A hot DMF solution (3 mL) of the ligand (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added to 2 mL of mixed MeOH/H2O (1:1, v/v) solution containing Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (59 mg, 0.16 mmol). On slow evaporation of the filtrate at RT, brown crystals were obtained in ∼42% yield. Anal. Calcd for C48H56N16O12Cl2Cu: C, 48.71; H, 4.77; N, 18.93%. Found: C, 48.85; H, 4.70; N, 18.80%. elements.content: Caution! Perchlorate salts are explosive (especially if they are dry) and should be handled with extreme caution. To minimize hazards associated with perchlorate complexes, the following precautions should be taken: (i) keep reaction scales to <100 mg, (ii) do not heat the complexes above 200 °C, not exceeding the heating rate of 5 °C/min, and (iii) carry out all reactions in an efficient fume hood!

A crystal of 1 was heated at 70 °C for 4 h under vacuum to obtain 1′.

Synthesis of {[Cu(azim)(Cl)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4′</bold>)

A crystal of 4 kept in water at room temperature for 2 days affords 4′.

Results and Discussion

All the coordination polymers, once isolated, are found to be stable in air and slightly soluble in DMF and DMSO but insoluble in other common organic solvents or water. IR spectra of the compounds show the carbonyl stretching frequency at ∼1670 cm–1 due to lattice DMF molecules and a broad band centered around 1085–1092 cm–1 due to ionic ClO4¯ anions. In 4′, a broad peak in the region 3425 cm–1 indicates the presence of lattice water molecules.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structure determination at 100 K reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and the asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) ion, four halves of crystallographically independent ligand units, three DMF molecules, and two ClO4¯ anions in the lattice. Each Zn(II) ion exhibits distorted tetrahedral geometry with ligation from imidazole N of four different ligand units (Figure a). All M–N bond distances are different: Zn1–N1 = 1.979(4) Å, Zn1–N4 = 1.999(4) Å, Zn1–N7 = 2.007(4) Å, and Zn1–N10 = 1.985(4) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Single-crystal X-ray structure determination at 100 K reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and the asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) ion, four halves of crystallographically independent ligand units, three DMF molecules, and two ClO4¯ anions in the lattice. Each Zn(II) ion exhibits distorted tetrahedral geometry with ligation from imidazole N of four different ligand units (Figure a). All M-N bond distances are different: Zn1-N1 = 1.979(4) Å, Zn1-N4 = 1.999(4) Å, Zn1-N7 = 2.007(4) Å, and Zn1-N10 = 1.985(4) Å.

elements.content: Each ligand binds two Zn(II) ions through imidazole N, and each Zn(II) ion, in turn, is connected to four ligand units to form an infinite 2D structure. These 2D layers are composed of M4L4 grids with distances between two metal ions as 18.94 and 18.85 Å (Figures b and ). These 2D layers are further connected by azim moieties to form an overall 1D wave like infinite chain structure viewed down the crystallographic c axis (See , Figure S14). The guest DMF molecules and ClO4¯ anions are encapsulated between the layers.

For better understanding of the structure, a topological analysis approach is employed; on considering all Zn(II) ions as four-connected nodes and the shortest circuit as a four-membered ring, 1 can be simplified as a four-connected 44 sql net (Figure ).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit in 2 consists of a Cu(II) ion seating on a center of symmetry, crystallographically independent two halves of ligand units, one coordinated DMF and one lattice DMF molecule besides one ClO4¯ anion. The metal ion shows distorted octahedral geometry where the equatorial plane contains four imidazole N atoms (Cu1–N1 = 2.012(4) and Cu1–N4 = 2.008(4) Å) and the two substantially longer axial positions are occupied by O atoms of two DMF molecules (Cu1–O1 = 2.425(3) Å) (Figure a). The ligand bridges metal ions to form a 2D rhombus grid structure (Figure b) with the distances of 19.27 and 19.71 Å between two metal ions. Both phenyl rings of each ligand moiety are nearly coplanar, while imidazole rings are twisted significantly with respect to the phenyl rings, ∼30.8°(7) (C3–N2–C4–C9). Lattice DMF molecules and ClO4¯ anions occupy the void spaces in the grid. The resulting 2D rhombus grid layers are stacked on top of one another in ABAB fashion (Figure a). The interplanar distance is ∼4.66 Å signifying moderately strong supramolecular interactions between the layers (Figure b). Topological analysis of 2 shows that each metal ion acts as a four-connected node and is bridged by a two-connected ligand unit to form a 44 sql net (Figure c).

elements.content: The X-ray structure of complex 3 reveals that the asymmetric unit consists of a half Zn(II) ion, a half of ligand, and a HCOO¯ anion. The HCOO¯ anion is generated in situ by the hydrolysis of a DMF molecule under solvothermal conditions. The Zn(II) ion exhibits distorted tetrahedral geometry with ligation from two imidazole N atoms from two ligand units and two O atoms from two HCOO¯ anions (Zn1–N1 = 2.013(3) and Zn1–O1 = 1.953(3) Å; Figure a). Each ligand bridges two metal centers to form an infinite 1D zigzag chain structure (Figure b). The C7 and C8 atoms of one benzene ring in the azim ligand are disordered over two positions with occupancy of 0.5. Similarly, the N3 atom of the azo group is also disordered over two positions with occupancy of 0.5. The observed disorder in 3 is attributable to an interconversion between two conformers (Scheme ), triggered by a bicycle pedal motion. Due to a low energy barrier, the two conformations interconvert faster than the time scale used to collect X-ray data. The resulting 1D chains form a supramolecular 3D structure by hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions (centroid–centroid distance ∼3.80 Å and slippage of ∼1.30 Å) (Figure c).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 4 reveals that Cu(II) ion has been reduced to Cu(I) under the prevailing solvothermal conditions. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cu(I) ion, one ligand, and one Cl¯ anion. The metal adopts a T-shaped coordination geometry with ligation from two imidazole N atoms from two different ligand units (Cu–N = 1.908(2) and 1.914(2) Å) and the Cl¯ anion (Cu–Cl = 2.448(11) Å) (Figure a). The ligand bridges two metal centers to generate a 1D chain along the crystallographic c axis (Figure b). Each chain is further involved in hydrogen-bonding and π–π interactions with neighboring chains to generate an overall 3D structure (Figure c).

elements.content: Thermal stabilities of all four complexes were examined. Complex 1 shows weight loss of ∼19.71% in the temperature range 100–240 °C that corresponds to loss of all lattice DMF molecules. The desolvated framework is found to be stable up to ∼380 °C. Complex 2 exhibits a weight loss of ∼24.70% within the temperature range 70–150 °C that corresponds to the release of both lattice and coordinated DMF molecules from the framework. Decomposition of the complex is accomplished only above 350 °C. Complexes 3 and 4 are also thermally stable up to 270 °C; beyond this temperature decomposition takes place in each case (see Figures S10–S13, ).

elements.content: The organic linker having an azo group in the center is capable of undergoing bicycle pedal motion (Scheme ). This pedal motion can be brought about by heat or via introduction of a suitable solvent.
elements.clean_text:
Solvent and Heat-Induced Reversible SC-SC Pedal Motion

The organic linker having an azo group in the center is capable of undergoing bicycle pedal motion (Scheme ). This pedal motion can be brought about by heat or via introduction of a suitable solvent.

elements.content: Compound 1 shows heat-induced pedal motion. To investigate this, a suitable crystal of 1 (mother crystal) is chosen. On careful heating at 70 °C for 4 h under vacuum, complex {[Zn(azim)2]·(ClO4)2·(2.25DMF)} n (1′) is obtained without losing crystallinity. Although this crystal is of poor quality and several cracks developed, still single-crystal X-ray data could be collected on this. The overall framework in 1′ remains unchanged although significant changes are observed in the dimensions of the rhombic grid with respect to 1. The diagonal M···M distances of 25.699 and 27.716 Å (in 1) change to 24.705 and 29.263 Å, respectively, in 1′ although the Zn–N distances in both structures are found to be almost identical. This change in the M···M distances is brought about due to bicycle pedal motion of the diphenyldiazene moiety of the ligand within the M4L4 rhombic grid framework in 1′ (Figure a). Now, the phenyl rings no longer remain coplanar but are twisted, forming a dihedral angle of 6.13° with respect to each other. Similarly, imidazole rings are further twisted forming a dihedral angle of ∼47.13° with respect to each other. In addition to this heat-induced bicycle pedal motion, slight movement of the ClO4¯ anions are also observed. One of the ions moved toward (Zn···Cl, 5.093 to 5.035 Å) while the other moved away (Zn···Cl, 5.005 to 5.040 Å), from the nearest metal ion.

elements.content: In the case of 4, guest-induced bicycle pedal motion is observed. When a crystal of 4 (mother crystal) was kept in H2O for 2 days, it became shinier and afforded {[Cu(azim)(Cl)]·H2O} n (4′) while maintaining its crystallinity. Single-crystal X-ray studies reveal that both the crystal system and space group change from monoclinic P2/c in 4 to triclinic P1̅ in 4′. The Cu–N bond distances are nearly same, while Cu–Cl distances differ significantly (from 2.448 Å in 4 to 2.801 Å in 4′). Lattice water molecules get incapsulated within the space between 1D chains in 4′. The increment in the Cu–Cl distance in 4′ maybe due to strong H-bonding interactions of the chloride with these lattice water molecules. Removal of water molecules from the framework by heating and its readmission occurs in SC–SC fashion resulting in the pedal motion of the diphenyldiazene moiety of the ligand (Figure b). Thus, this pedal motion is reversible in nature. With the pedal motion, an appreciable change in the dihedral angle between the phenyl rings takes place (from 49.66° in 4 to 13.30° in 4′) with concomitant movement of the imidazole rings toward coplanarity (dihedral angle 77.75° to 10.90°). The transparency and morphology of the crystals 1 and 4 (mother crystals) are retained during the course of all SC–SC transformations as depicted in the photographs taken (Figure S15, ).

elements.content: Complexes 1 and 2 were subjected to gas adsorption studies. The as-synthesized 1 and 2 were activated by immersing in DCM for 3 days followed by heating at 120 °C overnight under vacuum to remove the guest solvent molecules. Frameworks remain intact after desolvation as confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figures S6 and S7, ). To evaluate the adsorption capacity of desolvated frameworks, gas adsorption studies were conducted at low pressure on the activated samples with N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K. N2 did not diffuse into the pores of 1 at 77 K and exhibited negligible surface adsorption at p/p o ≈ 1 (Figure a), while slight (∼10 cm3/g at p/p o = 1) CO2 adsorption is observed at 195 K (Figure b). The low N2 sorption at 77 K vs a higher CO2 uptake at higher temperature seems to be simply a kinetic effect for very small pore sizes. On the other hand, complex 2 shows a typical type I adsorption isotherm at 77 K. Interestingly, the sorption isotherm reveals that there is slight adsorption at low pressure.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Studies

Complexes 1 and 2 were subjected to gas adsorption studies. The as-synthesized 1 and 2 were activated by immersing in DCM for 3 days followed by heating at 120 °C overnight under vacuum to remove the guest solvent molecules. Frameworks remain intact after desolvation as confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figures S6 and S7, ). To evaluate the adsorption capacity of desolvated frameworks, gas adsorption studies were conducted at low pressure on the activated samples with N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K. N2 did not diffuse into the pores of 1 at 77 K and exhibited negligible surface adsorption at p/p o ~ 1 (Figure a), while slight (~10 cm3/g at p/p o = 1) CO2 adsorption is observed at 195 K (Figure b). The low N2 sorption at 77 K vs a higher CO2 uptake at higher temperature seems to be simply a kinetic effect for very small pore sizes. On the other hand, complex 2 shows a typical type I adsorption isotherm at 77 K. Interestingly, the sorption isotherm reveals that there is slight adsorption at low pressure.

elements.content: Complexes exhibiting lumniscence properties are of immence current research interest because of their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electrochemical displays, and so on. CPs with d10 closed-shell electronic configuration have been found to show excellent lumniscence properties owing to their higher stability over organic ligands as well as ability to tune emission wavelength of the organic ligands upon binding with metals. The lumniscence properties of 1–5 and metal-free ligand azim were investigated in the solid state at the room temperature and are depicted collectively in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Lumniscence Properties

Complexes exhibiting lumniscence properties are of immence current research interest because of their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electrochemical displays, and so on. CPs with d10 closed-shell electronic configuration have been found to show excellent lumniscence properties owing to their higher stability over organic ligands as well as ability to tune emission wavelength of the organic ligands upon binding with metals. The lumniscence properties of 1-5 and metal-free ligand azim were investigated in the solid state at the room temperature and are depicted collectively in Figure .

elements.content: Solid-state emission spectra at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 11  Solid-state emission spectra at room temperature.

elements.content: Upon excitation at 304 nm, 1–4′ exhibit almost symmetrical emission bands at 420, 419, 426, 413, and 417 nm, respectively, while an emission of free ligand having λmax = 419 nm is observed. As the profile of the emission band of the ligand is similar to that of CPs, the emission of 1–4 and 4′ could be attributed to imidazole-based π–π* transitions or charge transfer transition between ligand and metal center. Incorporation of metal center effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiation-less decay or vibrational motion; thus, enhanced photoluminescence intensities of the four complexes were observed. As shown in Figure , we conclude that the photoluminescence intensity of complex 3 is the strongest, and a possible explanation is significant conformational rigidity of complex 3 with d10 closed-shell electronic configuration. In the case of 4′, the decrease in luminescence intensity may be due to the vibrational quenching by the presence of lattice water molecules. To probe the effect of water molecules on the intensity of luminescence, complex 4 is excited at 304 nm. The band attributed to imidazole-based π–π* transitions is greatly enhanced due to absence of vibrational quenching by lattice water molecules. Moreover, in the case of complex 2, the observed fluorescent intensity is even less than that of free ligand azim, which could be attributed to the presence of a paramagnetic center. The metal···metal distances are long enough (more than 3.6 Å) to rule out the possibility of cluster-centered transition caused by metal···metal interactions in all the CPs.

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized four novel coordination polymers of zinc and copper ions where the channel surfaces are decorated with azo functional groups having basic nitrogen sites. Frameworks 1 and 4 show dynamic pedal motion in response to external stimuli. The understanding of such motion in crystalline materials open a new door to interpret many dynamic phenomenon, irrespective of its detection, for solid state chemists. Gas adsorption measurements and luminescence properties have also been evaluated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have successfully synthesized four novel coordination polymers of zinc and copper ions where the channel surfaces are decorated with azo functional groups having basic nitrogen sites. Frameworks 1 and 4 show dynamic pedal motion in response to external stimuli. The understanding of such motion in crystalline materials open a new door to interpret many dynamic phenomenon, irrespective of its detection, for solid state chemists. Gas adsorption measurements and luminescence properties have also been evaluated.

The ligand bis(4-imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)-diazene was synthesized in two steps as described earlier.

Synthesis of {[Zn(azim)<sub>2</sub>]·(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·3DMF}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A hot DMF solution (3 mL) of the ligand (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added to 2 mL of mixed MeOH/H2O (1:1, v/v) solution containing Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O (∼60 mg, 0.16 mmol). On slow evaporation of the filtrate at RT, red crystals were obtained in ∼43% yield. Anal. Calcd for C45H49Cl2N15O11Zn: C, 48.59; H, 4.44; N, 18.88%. Found: C, 48.68; H, 4.51; N, 18.96%. IR (cm–1): 3119(m), 2927(w), 2854(w), 1669(s), 1602(m), 1526(s), 1435(w), 1407(m), 1335(m), 1308(s), 1092(s), 1008(s), 849(s), 773(m), 656(s).

Synthesis of {[Cu(azim)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]·(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·2DMF}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A hot DMF solution (3 mL) of the ligand (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added to 2 mL of mixed MeOH/H2O (1:1, v/v) solution containing Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (59 mg, 0.16 mmol). On slow evaporation of the filtrate at RT, brown crystals were obtained in ∼42% yield. Anal. Calcd for C48H56N16O12Cl2Cu: C, 48.71; H, 4.77; N, 18.93%. Found: C, 48.85; H, 4.70; N, 18.80%. IR (cm–1): 3135(m), 2926(w), 1659(s), 1601(m), 1518(s), 1388(m), 1329(w), 1303(s), 1086(s), 962(m), 848(s), 739(m), 655(s), 621(s).

Synthesis of {[Zn(azim)(HCOO)<sub>2</sub>]}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture containing the ligand (40 mg, 0.13 mmol) and ZnCl2·6H2O (18 mg, 0.13 mmol) in 3 mL of DMF, 1 mL of MeOH, and 1 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon lined autoclave and heated under autogenous pressure to 120 °C for 2 days and then allowed to cool to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C per minute. Block shaped red colored crystals of 3 were collected in ∼34% yield. Anal. Calcd for C20H16N6O4Zn: C, 51.14; H, 3.43; N, 17.89%. Found: C, 51.20; H, 3.49; N, 17.82%. IR (cm–1): 3125(m), 2825(m), 2708(w), 1626(s), 1605(s), 1513(s), 1367(m), 1309(s), 1250(m), 1130(m), 1066(s), 1008(s), 963(s), 849(s), 761(m), 646(m).

Synthesis of {[Cu(azim)(Cl)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture containing the ligand (40 mg, 0.13 mmol) and CuCl2·6H2O (17 mg, 0.13 mmol) in 3 mL of DMF, 1 mL of MeOH, and 1 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon lined autoclave and heated under autogenous pressure to 120 °C for 2 days and then allowed to cool to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C per minute. Block shaped orange colored crystals of 4 were collected in ∼37% yield. Anal. Calcd For C18H14N6ClCu: C, 52.30; H, 3.41; N, 20.33%. Found: C, 52.15; H, 3.48; N, 20.44%. IR (cm–1): 3127(m), 1624(m), 1514(s), 1430(w), 1302(s), 1264(w), 1242(s), 1157(m), 1069(s), 961(s), 843(s), 738(m), 763(m).

cln_elements.content:
Thermal stabilities of all four complexes were examined. Complex 1 shows weight loss of ∼19.71% in the temperature range 100–240 °C that corresponds to loss of all lattice DMF molecules. The desolvated framework is found to be stable up to ∼380 °C. Complex 2 exhibits a weight loss of ∼24.70% within the temperature range 70–150 °C that corresponds to the release of both lattice and coordinated DMF molecules from the framework. Decomposition of the complex is accomplished only above 350 °C. Complexes 3 and 4 are also thermally stable up to 270 °C; beyond this temperature decomposition takes place in each case (see Figures S10–S13, ).

However, it shows N2 uptake of 44.44 cm3 g–1 at high pressure region (p/p o ≈ 1.0). The adsorption experiment for 2 confirms the microporous nature of the framework. Moreover, the CO2 adsorption isotherm indicates that at very low pressure 2 shows CO2 uptake of ∼31.17 cm3 g–1 (p/p o ≈ 0.09) and gets saturated at p/p o ≈ 0.90 with uptake of ∼44.54 cm3 g–1 (Figure c). The adsorption isotherms show hysteresis due to the dynamic nature of the framework. The BET surface areas of 1 and 2 are 54.45 and 70.24 m2/g, respectively. Therefore, the nature of channels and pore surfaces composed of the base functionalities (−NN– group) and metal ions that can interact with linear CO2 molecules could be the crucial factors for such selectivity.
